If he stays at home, the seven jewels … (61)

If, however, he leaves the house, he will attain the perfect Buddha rank. (cf 61, slightly different)
... This one, at the age of twenty-nine, became appalled by old age and dying; at midnight
... Having rejected the doctrine of Ārāḍa, Udraka and the other ṛṣis, (he) for six years (observed) the hard to (observe austerity)
... having received from Nandā and Nandabalā the rice pap, condensed sixteen times, in the Bodhi forest,
he took his seat with firm decisiveness on the diamond throne. (The army) of the god Māra, with his thirty-six myriads of companies, (he defeated) ...
... he obtained the matchless perfect status of Buddha (anuttara-samyak-sambodhi). || In the Viśikko [tune] || The earth trembled with joy, (in all) directions
... in the sky, in the ten directions, joy of the beings was born. They took confidence in the root of happiness (kuśalamūla) of the good beings
... the words ‘Reverence to Buddha’ [namo buddha] were heard among laughter and music. 1. From the Gautama family and the lineage of Ikṣvā(ku)
... having learned everything that can be learned, having removed everything that can be removed, wise and disciplined, whom one cannot see enough,
... striving for ..., teacher of gods and men, refuge and hope of living beings,
... wondrous. Oh, how wonderful! this one being ... thus only
Oh how wonderful! … merely one being … in such a way … (cf 61)
... The god says: Listen, noble one! When
... at the invitation of (god) Brahmā, (he went to the vicinity) of the city of Vārāṇāsī.

p.note: The commentary is basically adapted from 62.
This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami I, 15a11-16a11. See also 193-4.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 62.
ākessu is unknown to , but they refer to TA āk “end” (but TB āke); claiming that, therefore, ākessu is probably a loanword from TB.
MaitrHami 1, 15 a11-14 has “This is my last birth”. Mahāvastu. II. 24, 9: ayaṃ dāniṃ eko bhavo paścimo tti.

MaitrHami 1, 15 a19-25: “(An astrologer said:) “If he stays at home, he will be a Cakravartin-emperor, ruling over the four directions and being equipped with the seven jewels. If he leaves the home (becomes a monk), he will get the saṃyak-sambodhi”.”

ārāḍeṃ: 16, note 41: “[ist] zu A (a)rāḍeṃ udrakenäṣṣ zu korrigieren”; but since there is only Skt. Ārāḍa, nowhere and never Arāḍa, Thomas’ correction must be rescinded.māski implies that “he practiced the severe religious austerities”, Skt. tapas, cf. MaitrHami 1, 15 b10.
Here in the original fragment only a small point is left, obviously part of the Brāhmī sign na. But the transcription of Thomas is [·n](a)ndāṃ. Thomas’ signs [ ]( ) are all superfluous.
MaitrHami 1, 15 b13-14: “Having enjoyed the 16 times strengthened pap offered by the two sisters Nandā and Nandabalā.”
17, note 43 claims that “von dem Akṣara [p](r)ā ist in der Tat noch ein deutlicher Rest erkennbar.”, which 62 reject out of hand.
viśikkonaṃ: two stanzas of 4 x 18 (7/7/4) syllables. For the following description, cf. MaitrHami 1, 15 b22-30.

spantar: correctly identified as the 3pl.pret.act. to spänt- (157) “to trust” (someone, something) by 62. However, as pointed out by 283, there is no reason to take this form to stand for spāntar (as per 279): it is regular.
riya- is to be completed as riya(c kātse), according to the parallel text, MaitrHami 1, 16 a11f.
